rows.notes: one of the most frequent verbs in the Hebrew Bible; ~5,300 occurrences
frequently used metaphorically for living righteously (e.g., 'walk with God')
III-He verb; Niphal = to appear / be seen
intimate, experiential knowledge; source of the name 'Yeda'
~2,000 occurrences; common in covenantal contexts
used for creation, work, and covenant-keeping
hollow verb (I-Aleph); very common motion verb
hearing implies obedience in Hebrew thought; root of 'Shema' (Deut. 6:4)
used for calling names, calling out to God, and reading aloud
the theological concept of repentance and restoration; ~1,000 occurrences
III-Aleph verb; used for finding favor (grace) before God
I-Nun (behaves as hollow); very common; used in marriage contexts
used of God sending prophets and angels
standing before God implies service and readiness
used both for sitting and for dwelling/living in a place
used for going up to Jerusalem; the burnt offering is the ʿolah (that which goes up)
contrast with ʿalah; used of descending to Egypt, Sheol, etc.
III-He verb; used of building the Temple and the nation
III-He verb; God 'answering' prayer is a key biblical theme
physical falling and moral failure; 'fallen' heroes and cities
Piel (intensive) is the most common; God blessing people is central to the covenant
emotional and covenantal love; God's love for Israel; ~215 occurrences
'Fear of the LORD' is the beginning of wisdom (Prov. 1:7)
root of melek (king) and malkhut (kingdom)
keeping the commandments and covenants; ~470 occurrences
grammatically plural, theologically singular when referring to the God of Israel; most common divine name (~2,600×)
the Tetragrammaton; ~6,800 occurrences; traditionally not pronounced; read as ʾAdonai
from ʾadon (lord/master); spoken in place of YHWH during reading
melek, malkenu = our king; malkah = queen
construct state: ben- (son of); plural banim; key to genealogies and messianic titles
construct: bat- (daughter of); plural banot; Bat-sheba = daughter of an oath
ʾavinu = our father; ʾavraham = father of many nations
plural ʾimmot; root of the word for nation (ʾummah)
contrast with ʾishah (woman/wife); plural ʾanashim (irregular)
related to ʾish (man) by popular etymology in Gen. 2:23
'My people Israel'; ʿammi = my people; Am Yisrael = the people of Israel
Eretz Yisrael = Land of Israel; also used for 'the earth' in Gen. 1:1
grammatically dual; 'In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth' (Gen. 1:1)
'The hand of the LORD' symbolizes divine power; plural yadayim
the center of thought and decision in Hebrew; 'with all your heart' (Deut. 6:5)
the whole living being, not just the immaterial soul; 'the LORD breathed nefesh into man' (Gen. 2:7)
Ruach HaQodesh = Holy Spirit; the spirit of God hovering over the waters (Gen. 1:2)
'The word of the LORD came to…'; dabar is both word and event/deed
the Pentateuch and God's instruction; from yarah (to teach/direct)
the binding relationship between God and His people; appears ~280 times in the OT
loyal love within a covenant; God's characteristic attribute; ~248 occurrences; often untranslatable
related to ʾamen; God's truth is the bedrock of His character
much richer than absence of conflict; includes flourishing, wholeness, and right relationship
God's fundamental attribute; Qodesh HaQodashim = Holy of Holies
the visible, weighty presence of God; 'the glory of the LORD filled the tabernacle'
practical skill and moral discernment; personified in Proverbs 8 as a divine attribute
right action in accordance with God's standard; closely paired with mishpat (justice)
'Let justice roll down like waters' (Amos 5:24); God's just governance
both the act of sin and the sacrifice that atones for it; from chataʾ (to miss the mark)
deeper moral distortion than simple sin; includes the guilt and its punishment
one who speaks for God; the prophets (Nevi'im) form the second section of the Tanakh
the Aaronic priesthood; plural kohanim; Kohen HaGadol = High Priest
can refer to human messengers or divine angels; Malachi = 'my messenger'
Beit HaMiqdash = the Temple; Beth- in place names means 'house of'
plural ʿarim; Ir David = City of David (Jerusalem)
metaphorically, the path of life; 'the way of the LORD' (halakha comes from halak, to walk)
Yom Kippur = Day of Atonement; used for both a 24-hour day and an era ('day of the LORD')
the Hebrew day begins at sunset; the evening (ʿerev) precedes the morning (boqer)
always dual in form; living water (mayim chayyim) symbolizes the Spirit and purity
symbol of God's presence and judgment; the burning bush; fire on Sinai
'The righteous shall live by his faithfulness' (Hab. 2:4); basis of NT concept of faith
kinsman-redemption; the goʾel (redeemer) acts to restore what was lost
from shuv (to return); turning back to God; the central concept of the High Holy Days
'And God saw that it was good' (Gen. 1); used as a greeting: Yom Tov = Good Day / Holiday
Tree of the knowledge of good (tov) and evil (raʿ); can also mean 'disaster'
'Great is the LORD and greatly to be praised'; Gadol = the title 'the Great'
'Holy, holy, holy is the LORD of hosts' (Isa. 6:3); the Trisagion
El Chai = the Living God; Chai in Jewish culture is the symbol of life (numerical value 18)
'The LORD our God, the LORD is one' (Deut. 6:4, the Shema); unity can imply a compound unity
kol is used as a prefix or standalone: kol ha-ʾarets = all the earth
Rabbi = my great one / my teacher; Rav is a title of honor
'A new heart I will give you' (Ezek. 36:26); Chodesh = new month (from the new moon)
Yisrael may mean 'he who strives with God'; yashar implies moral integrity
the most common word in the Hebrew Bible; a prefix attached to the next word
one of the most frequent conjunctions; context determines its exact meaning
the relative pronoun and complementizer; also a name meaning 'blessed'
introduces conditional clauses; אִם לֹא = unless / if not
used with finite verbs; לֹא תִרְצַח = you shall not murder (6th commandment)
used with jussive/cohortative to express 'do not'; a softer prohibition than loʾ
additive particle; Gam zu letova = 'this also is for good'
temporal continuity: 'while there is still time'; 'again'
prefix preposition; Beresheet = In the beginning (Gen. 1:1)
prefix preposition; marks indirect object, purpose, and possession
prefix mi- before consonant; used for source, separation, and comparison
directional preposition; also a divine name: El = God (mighty one)
very versatile; 'the Spirit of God hovered over (ʿal) the waters'
Immanuel = God with us (ʿim + El)
'I will make my covenant between (bein) me and you'
